time and iteration

democratize PCG

Mentioned above, the time-saving of exponentially larger games.  I might use it as a novelty for smaller projects, but for something with eg big cities or just anything with a smaller team, there is no alternative.

Having to hardcode your PLG, which will be much less flexible to change. Also, when it is coded designers won't be able to play with it as easily. Having an external tool that exports (customizable) level data would be great. Especially if designers are able to work with it more easily.
Being able to have more content in my game
Assist with level design and generation with linking story and quest content with environment
Do quick defaults&templates to be edited later, but not in a game context *I do computational urban design
Populating a world with content (quests, encounters, side activities etc.)
If I need a diverse and rich world
Creating more content of the same quality in the same time as handcrafted

It is very genre-dependent, but procedural live generation can help keep games balanced during gameplay. Essentially, in what I do, it'd be extremely helpful to have procedural generation support subtle rubber-banding

I design games where the level is consumed once. I would like the level generation to alter the existing and designed by hand level to introduce variability with playthrough/player excursion in the level
role: Most of the above because indie :(

response: Accelerating my workflow
Ease of integration to game engines
time Saver : boiler code already done (don't want to implement known algorithms), fast, saves time for polish balancing etc
Creativity
Generating meaningful content which can engage users while maintaining an authored feel
Timesaving for repetitive and time consuming tasks such as set dressing which unlocks more scope possibilities
a new random map being generated for every play customised to specific settings
Provide infinite levels that retain the 'essence' of what makes a level fun/interesting in the first place.
Make lots of unique fun levels
Reduce development cost ($) to create content.
Avoid manually placed objects
Consistent asset quality that makes sense in the rest of the artistic context
More freedom in the level sections, so I could set the exit and have more organic results with the tool
To save time, that way we can work on more assets to add additional variation.
To get some base or groundwork to start from, or ideate from
Quickly adding variation to similar assets and easily populating a scene.
Enabling creative control on a large scale
Speed from what I imagine to what's on the screen

I don't think we need more tools, we need more knowledge. I like what BorisTheBrave & Oskar Stalberg do: explaining generation techniques. I think the knowledge should be readily available, but folks should design their own systems aligned with their own projects.
Show processes of how solution made decisions per asset.
Base its creation on existing level designs fed into it, to create variations or new layouts that speed up workflow whole remaining tonally consistent
Creating a gameplay space I can build of off. A generated piece of level could be used as a sketch for a challenge in a level, this would speed up the process of prototyping challenges in-game.
Difficulty for artists to use
replayable content workload
Making engaging levels when I don't consider myself a good level designer
Skip the setup steps that I have to do in each project just because the project slightly differs from the previous (in terms of tech used, pipeline or design constraints)
Take away the initial risk of dedicating time for setting up a PCG system.
Monotonous tasks.
More rapid and flexible implementation of art assets
High quality coverage of the basics (e.g. 'make a hospital ward') with easy customisation for me to build unique assets onto.
I want a PCG tool to help bridge the gap between the worlds and levels I imagine and my skill in bringing those worlds to life
Variation
Flexibility and control over level creation during quick iteration

Testing viability by running analytics. Combining elements into a level isn't what I'd use an of-the-shelf solution for. But something that could help test if a level is good, or at least works, that would be awesome.

I have artistic vision, but not necessarily the artistic/practical skills to implement that vision. I do have extensive programming and some design skills. So I can build a game, but I will struggle to make it look eye-catching unless I simplify the art style a lot. I would love a proc-gen tool that can cleverly add detail and decorate a basic block-out (in e.g. a 3D first-person shooter) such that it looks like a fully fledged level. So input: basic (BSP) geometry, perhaps with some mark-up that indicates design/semantic intentions - output: level that is decorated with details such as slants, trims, pipes, walls with depth, bridges that start and end properly, other procedural geometry, etc. That way, I can stay in control over the overall design of the level, and have the artistic details be figured out by a tool, much like an art director making a request. That way, I do not need to be dependent on finding a (specific) artist to fully implement my vision, or at the very least I can get something very decent looking already, which also helps with inspiration and motivation.
Reduce time on complex / boring stuff. Increase agency of level designer by suggesting content. Example: Create a world procedurally, create content more hand tailored.
Creating a large foundation for artists to manually tweak and iterate with.
Quick iteration on the algorithms themselves
Creating bigger worlds with less work (fewer people).
Tool simplicity combined with output variation
Create high quality content
Generating runtime based geometry that can also be generated in editor.
Making tools accessible to users unlocks massive UGC potential.
Speed of iterations/testing with gameplay
Make levels that fit well with the game.
Rich detailed worlds
Ability to properly modify by hand the results
I think a good PCG system forces me to introspect on implicit design constraints, and thereby help me expand the design space and variety of gameplay.
Ease of iteration and time reduced between itterations
Understand my generation process of creating levels and propose a generator graph that I can edit with the AI
Make intresting play spaces.
Adaptable generators
An easy solution to generate and blend well with landscapes
Create huge environments without doing all the manual labor (so a time (and budget) optimization)
